subs.text: A good, thoughtful thread on @helium as it appears today. And I did drop $450 on a hotspot. Will I make my money back? No idea. But helping to ‚Äúbuild‚Äù a decentralized network for IoT devices was worth it to me. Hopefully, the network will be used by many for its intended purpose. [link]
subs.rawText: A good, thoughtful thread on @helium as it appears today. And I did drop $450 on a hotspot. Will I make my money back? No idea. But helping to ‚Äúbuild‚Äù a decentralized network for IoT devices was worth it to me. Hopefully, the network will be used by many for its intended purpose. https://t.co/4A801Zea1a

subs.text: I should also note that the analysis on data usage so far is likely spot on. I‚Äôve had my hotspot for roughly 4 months and it has only seen 3 data packets in all that time. The network is there, but will devices use it is the bigger, more important question in my mind.
subs.rawText: I should also note that the analysis on data usage so far is likely spot on. I‚Äôve had my hotspot for roughly 4 months and it has only seen 3 data packets in all that time. The network is there, but will devices use it is the bigger, more important question in my mind.

subs.text: And one last data point in regards to data credit usage was $6,500 last month. The data cost is *dirt cheap*. 1 Helium data credit costs $0.00001. So the pricing model in that regard is completely disruptive for long-range IoT connectivity.
subs.rawText: And one last data point in regards to data credit usage was $6,500 last month. The data cost is *dirt cheap*. 1 Helium data credit costs $0.00001. So the pricing model in that regard is completely disruptive for long-range IoT connectivity.

subs.text: Woke up at 4am (not a rare occurrence these days) and decided to look deeper at #PopOS. My Dell XPS 15 has two NVME slots, so I threw a spare 256 GB SSD in there; no need to partition the Windows 11 drive. Pop is quite nice and approachable: *love* the auto-tiling feature. [link]

subs.text: July 2

@AlainLe89396509 Who marketed Chromebooks with a USP as ‚Äúlower price‚Äù, retailers? Maybe. But that isn‚Äôt, nor was it ever, a USP. In the beginning, you paid less because you had less capability and functionality. Chrome OS has always been about 3 S‚Äôs: Speed, Simplicity, Security. *That‚Äôs* the USP.
subs.rawText: @AlainLe89396509 Who marketed Chromebooks with a USP as ‚Äúlower price‚Äù, retailers? Maybe. But that isn‚Äôt, nor was it ever, a USP. In the beginning, you paid less because you had less capability and functionality. Chrome OS has always been about 3 S‚Äôs: Speed, Simplicity, Security. *That‚Äôs* the USP.

subs.text: @AlainLe89396509 Also for reference: The Windows version of the HP Elite Dragonfly is about $1,000 to $1,500 more than this HP Elite Dragonfly Chromebook. Mainly because they‚Äôre targeted at enterprise. [link]
subs.rawText: @AlainLe89396509 Also for reference: The Windows version of the HP Elite Dragonfly is about $1,000 to $1,500 more than this HP Elite Dragonfly Chromebook. Mainly because they‚Äôre targeted at enterprise. https://t.co/3ukTTXS2J8

subs.text: @AlainLe89396509 You can still buy a $200 - $300 (or less with sales) Chromebook. But these were never about ‚Äúbeing cheap‚Äù. That‚Äôs a myth based on the first Chromebooks using repurposed netbook hardware. Chrome OS devices also run Android apps and a full Linux install, so not all web based.
subs.rawText: @AlainLe89396509 You can still buy a $200 - $300 (or less with sales) Chromebook. But these were never about ‚Äúbeing cheap‚Äù. That‚Äôs a myth based on the first Chromebooks using repurposed netbook hardware. Chrome OS devices also run Android apps and a full Linux install, so not all web based.

subs.text: @AlainLe89396509 There are Chromebooks at nearly every budget / price point. And the internals of a Chromebook can be the same as a Windows laptop; parts cost the same, regardless of the operating system.
subs.rawText: @AlainLe89396509 There are Chromebooks at nearly every budget / price point. And the internals of a Chromebook can be the same as a Windows laptop; parts cost the same, regardless of the operating system.
